== External links ==
=== Court documents === * {{lexum-scc|2005|35}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051227221111/http://www.law.utoronto.ca/healthlaw/docs/chaoulli/CourtofAppeal_decision_eng.doc Court of Appeal decision] (translated from French) * Facta ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20051227213103/http://www.law.utoronto.ca/healthlaw/docs/chaoulli/ChaoulliFactum_english.doc Factum of Appellant] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20051227212126/http://www.law.utoronto.ca/healthlaw/docs/chaoulli/Factum_AGQebec_eng.pdf AG Quebec Respondent factum] ** [https://web.archive.org/web/20051227204821/http://www.law.utoronto.ca/healthlaw/docs/chaoulli/AGCanada_Factum_English.doc AG Canada intervener factum]
=== Analysis === * [http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/content/full/173/2/142 Supreme disagreement: The highest court affirms an empty right] - analysis in the [[CMAJ]] by lawyer Colleen Flood and Cancer Care Ontario President Terrence Sullivan. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060512192031/http://www.mapleleafweb.com/features/medicare/charter-heath-care/index.html analysis of case from mapleleafweb.com] * [http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/rapidpdf/cmaj.050728v1.pdf Supreme Court slaps for-sale sign on medicare] - analysis by [[Lawrie McFarlane]], deputy minister of health for [[British Columbia]]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060210020725/http://cupe.ca/www/insidechaoulli "inside Chaoullli"] analysis by [[Canadian Union of Public Employees|CUPE]]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070101163402/http://www.santepop.qc.ca/chaoulli/colloque_f.asp Réseau de recherche en santé des populations du Québec] conference on Chaoulli containing various analyses (French) * [http://www.cprn.org/doc.cfm?doc=1394&l=en A Hitchhiker's Guide to Chaoulli] Comment on the practical effect of the Chaoulli decision by Tom McIntosh, Director of [[Canadian Policy Research Networks (CPRN)]], Health Network
=== Press reports === * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110527074734/http://www.westernstandard.ca/website/article.php?id=299 Freedom Fighter ] - Western Standard article by [[Peter Jaworski]]. * [http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/05/23/news/doc.php A doctor challenges Canada's health care system ] - International Herald Tribune article by [[Clifford Krauss]]. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060302151908/http://www.torontofreepress.com/2005/weinreb062105.htm Chaoulli decision was not judicial activism ] - a commentary by [[Arthur Weinrib]]. * [http://www.cmaj.ca/cgi/content/full/173/2/117 Lament for a health care system] - a [[CMAJ]] editorial about the court ruling.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chaoulli V. Quebec (Attorney General)}} [[Category:Health in Quebec]] [[Category:Section Seven Charter case law]] [[Category:Supreme Court of Canada cases]] [[Category:2005 in Canadian case law]] [[Category:Health law in Canada]] [[Category:Medical lawsuits]] [[Category:Quebec law]]

'''Collaborative Care''' is a [[healthcare]] philosophy and movement that has many names, models, and definitions that often includes the provision of mental health, behavioral health and substance use services in primary care. Similar ideas include: [[Integrated care]], [[Primary Care Behavioral health|Primary Care Behavioral Health]], [[Integrated care system]]s, and [[shared care]]. The [[Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality]] (AHRQ) published an overview of many different models and the [[research]] that supports them.Butler M, Kane RL, McAlpine D, Kathol, RG, Fu SS, Hagedorn H, Wilt TJ. Integration of Mental Health/Substance Abuse and Primary Care No. 173 (Prepared by the Minnesota Evidence-based Practice Center under Contract No. 290-02-0009.) AHRQ Publication No. 09-E003. Rockville, MD. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. October 2008. The key features of Collaborative Care models are:
*Integration of [[mental health professional]]s in [[primary care]] medical settings
*Close collaboration between [[mental health]] and medical/[[nursing]] providers
*Focus on treating the whole person and whole family. There are organisations in many countries promoting these ideas such as the American [[Collaborative Family Healthcare Association]]. == See also == [[Integrated care]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Health care]] {{health-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Use Irish English|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox news event | date = {{start date|2012|10|28|df=y}} | image = Savita Halappanavar mural, Dublin.jpg | caption = A mural of Savita Halappanavar outside the Bernard Shaw Pub in [[Portobello, Dublin|Portobello]], [[Dublin]]. | place = [[University Hospital Galway]], [[Galway]], Ireland | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | cause = [[Septicemia]] and [[multiple organ failure]] }} '''Savita Halappanavar''' was a 31-year-old Indian dentist who died on 28 October 2012 at [[University Hospital Galway]] in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] due to the complications of a [[septic miscarriage]] at 17 weeks' gestation. The miscarriage took seven days to unfold, and early in the process, when it was clear that the miscarriage was inevitable, Halappanavar requested an abortion. At that time the medical team had not diagnosed her with a blood infection, and her request was denied because the medical team did not judge that her life was in danger. The medical team eventually did diagnose the sepsis and began trying to treat it, and when they determined that Halappanavar's life was in danger they had planned to administer [[misoprostol]] to induce delivery, but the miscarriage completed before they were able to. The sepsis continued developing and she died of [[cardiac arrest]] caused by the sepsis.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|22–53}} Her death caused controversy at the time, nationally and internationally, leading to protests and marches.
After her death, a Coroner's Inquest was held, finding that she died of [[medical misadventure]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/savita-inquest-the-coroners-9-recommendations-876864-Apr2013/|newspaper=The Journal.ie|title=Savita inquest: The coroner's nine recommendations endorsed by the jury|date=19 April 2013|first=Sinead|last=O'Carroll}}</ref> The [[Health Service Executive|HSE]] and [[HIQA]] conducted an investigation. Both criticized the team for not diagnosing the sepsis soon enough and for not using already-standard screening tools for detecting and managing maternal sepsis, and for poor keeping of medical records, poor communication at shift changes, and failure to notify staff with needed expertise, and criticized the administration of the hospital for the poor system in which the team failed. They made recommendations about training and policies for the hospital locally along with a number of national recommendations, including the creation of a laboratory system to coordinate a national response to emerging [[Antimicrobial resistance|microbial threats]].<ref name=hiqa2103>{{cite web|title=Investigation into the safety, quality and standards of services provided by the Health Service Executive to patients, including pregnant women, at risk of clinical deterioration, including those provided in University Hospital Galway, and as reflected in the care and treatment provided to Savita Halappanavar|url=https://www.hiqa.ie/sites/default/files/2017-01/Patient-Safety-Investigation-UHG.pdf|publisher=Health Information and Quality Authority|date=7 October 2013}} {{cite press release|url=https://www.hiqa.ie/hiqa-news-updates/patient-safety-investigation-report-published-health-information-and-quality|publisher=HIQA|date=9 October 2013|title=Press release: Patient Safety Investigation Report published by Health Information and Quality Authority (Savita Halappanavar)}}</ref> The HSE also recommended changes to the legal situation and training of doctors about the law.<ref name=HSEreport/>
The law in force at the time (the [[Offences against the Person Act 1861]]), stated that the act of abortion, where there was no immediate physiological threat to the woman's life to continue the pregnancy, was a [[Abortion in the Republic of Ireland#Law|criminal offence]] punishable by [[life imprisonment]]. Following a ruling of the [[Supreme Court of Ireland]] in 1992—now known in Ireland as the [[Attorney General v. X|X case]]—terminations are allowed under certain circumstances, where "a pregnant woman's life is at risk because of pregnancy, including the risk of suicide".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/most-tds-will-back-legislation-on-x-case-3296831.html|title= Most TDs will back legislation on X Case|work=Irish Independent|date=18 November 2012}}</ref> However at the time of Halappanavar's death, there was legal uncertainty regarding the precise circumstances in which this exception to preserve the life of the mother would apply in practice, as the matter had not yet been enacted in legislation. The [[Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013]] was passed as a result of her death.
==Death==
Savita Halappanavar, 17 weeks pregnant with her first baby, went to the hospital with her husband Praveen on 21 October 2012 complaining about back pain. She was examined and discharged, and then returned to the hospital a few hours later after she felt something "coming down." An examination showed that the gestational sac had protruded into her vagina, almost to the opening. She was admitted to the hospital for observation, as a miscarriage appeared to be inevitable.<ref name=HSEreport>{{cite web|last=External Independent Committee|title=Investigation of Incident 50278 from time of patient’s self referral to hospital on the 21st of October 2012 to the patient’s death on the 28th of October, 2012.|url=https://www.hse.ie/eng/services/news/nimtreport50278.pdf|publisher=[[Health Service Executive|HSE]]|date=June 2013}} {{cite press release|title=HSE publishes Report of the Investigation into the death of Ms. Savita Halappanavar|publisher=[[Health Service Executive|HSE]]|url=https://www.hse.ie/eng/services/news/media/pressrel/newsarchive/2013archive/jun13/savitareport.html|language=en|date=13 June 2013}}</ref>{{rp|22–26}} Her [[Premature rupture of membranes|water broke]] just after midnight on 22 October.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|29}} On the 23 the Halappanavars discussed terminating the pregnancy early with one of the consultant doctors: according to the 2013 Health Service report: "O&G Consultant 1 stated that the patient and her husband were advised of Irish law in relation to this. At interview the consultant stated 'Under Irish law, if there’s no evidence of risk to the life of the mother, our hands are tied so long as there’s a fetal heart'. The consultant stated that if risk to the mother was to increase a termination would have been possible, but that it would be based on actual risk and not a theoretical risk of infection 'we can’t predict who is going to get an infection'".<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|33}} Midwife manager Ann Maria Burke attempted to calm the couple and explained that the termination cannot be carried out because Ireland is "a Catholic country".<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[RTÉ News and Current Affairs|RTÉ News]]|title= Midwife confirms she told Savita Halappanavar Ireland a 'Catholic country'|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/health/2013/0410/380613-savita-halappanavar-inquest/|date=11 April 2013}}</ref> Halappanavar began to develop signs of [[sepsis]], and the hospital decided to insert a [[central venous catheter|central line]] to better manage her condition, and had also decided to administer [[misoprostol]] to induce delivery; the medication was not given because on 24 October she delivered a [[stillborn]] female child in the procedure room where the central line was being inserted.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|44–46}} The sepsis continued to worsen, and at 1:09am, on Sunday 28 October, she died from [[cardiac arrest]] caused by the sepsis.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|53}}
==Reaction== On 3 November 2012, friends and family of the Halappanavars contacted local pro-choice groups (Galway Pro-Choice) to find out what they could do, with dozens of her friends and family meeting in person on the 6th. Galway Pro-Choice put them in contact with ''[[The Irish Times]]'' journalist Kitty Holland,<ref name="irishexaminer.com">{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/columnists/victoria-white/savitas-death-is-not-about-abortion-it-is-about-medical-negligence-247993.html|first=Victoria|last=White|title=Savita’s death is not about abortion, it is about medical negligence Thursday|date=31 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/global-observers-horrified-and-bewildered-by-savita-case-1.2568298|title=Global observers horrified and bewildered by Savita case|first=Kitty|last=Holland|date=11 March 2016|quote=Neither he, nor the close-knit Indian community in Galway, who first approached The Irish Times about what had happened to Savita}}</ref> on 7 November.<ref name="Galway Pro-Choice">{{cite web|url=http://galwayprochoice.org/2012/12/galway-pro-choice-were-approached-by-savitas-friends/|publisher=Galway Pro-Choice|title=Galway Pro Choice Were Approached by Savita’s Friends|date=2012-11-21|accessdate=2015-02-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211201358/http://galwayprochoice.org/2012/12/galway-pro-choice-were-approached-by-savitas-friends/|archive-date=11 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Holland 70">{{cite book |last=Holland|first=Kitty|title=Savita: The Tragedy that Shook a Nation|publisher=Transworld Ireland|page=70|isbn=978-1848271838}}</ref> Pro-choice groups then organised on the Irish Choice Network (ICN) email group before the story broke.<ref name="Irish Independent">{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/prochoice-activists-got-tipoff-on-tragic-death-28902755.html |title=Pro-choice activists got tip-off on tragic death | work=Irish Independent}}</ref>
Halappanavar's death became public after the ''[[Tonight with Vincent Browne]]'' programme showed front-page stories by ''The Irish Times'' and the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' newspapers on 13 November 2012.<ref name="it-savita-story-resonates-around-world">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/1117/1224326702387.html|title=Savita story resonates around the world|date=17 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012|last=Mullally|first=Una|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]}}</ref> This resulted in the news being disseminated on [[Twitter]], including tweets by journalists [[Caitlin Moran]] and [[India Knight]], and coverage by publications such as [[BBC News]], the British edition of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', ''[[Daily Mirror]]'', and ''[[The Independent]]'' newspapers.<ref name="it-savita-story-resonates-around-world" />
On 14 November 2012, more than 2,000 people gathered in her memory and to protest Ireland's abortion laws outside the [[Dáil]] in Dublin.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/savita-demonstration-leinster-house-674695-Nov2012/|title=‘Over 2,000′ attend sit-down protest for Halappanavar at Leinster House|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|work=The Journal| date=14 November 2012}}</ref> In addition, a candle-light vigil was held in Cork.<ref name="bbc1">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20321741|title=Woman dies after abortion request 'refused' at Galway hospital|work=BBC News|date=14 November 2012}}</ref> The government's expert committee in abortion, to address the ''[[A, B and C v Ireland]]'' judgement, handed in its report to the Department of Health the evening before the new story broke.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/taoiseach-expert-group-delivered-abortion-report-last-night-574183.html|title=Taoiseach: Expert group delivered abortion report last night|date=14 November 2012|accessdate=9 June 2016|publisher=Breaking News.ie}}</ref>
Halappanavar's death led to protests in [[Galway]], particularly from the local Indian expatriate community.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/nov/16/ireland-abortion-savita-halappanavar-indian-envoy|title=Savita Halappanavar 'would still be alive if she had been treated in India'|work=The Guardian|date=16 November 2012|location=London|first=Henry|last=McDonald}}</ref> On 14 November ''The Daily Mirror'' reported that the University Hospital was the subject of several investigations.<ref name="mir12">{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/savita-halappanavar-husband-claims-pregnant-1435830|title=Savita Halappanavar: Husband claims pregnant wife would still be alive if doctors hadn't 'refused' her an abortion, however the actual Medical Report states that this was not the case.|date=14 November 2012|last=Rudd|first=Andy|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror|''The Mirror'']]}}</ref> Halappanavar had been one of the organisers of the annual Galway [[Diwali]] festival, which was cancelled in response to her death.<ref name="cbs">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57549651/husband-ireland-hospital-denied-savita-halappanavar-life-saving-abortion-because-it-is-a-catholic-country/|title=Husband: Ireland hospital denied Savita Halappanavar life saving abortion because it is a "Catholic country"|publisher=[[CBS News]]|work=CBS News|date=14 November 2012}}</ref>
There were calls upon the [[Taoiseach]] to secure an external enquiry into the circumstances surrounding Halappanavar's death.<ref name=bbc1/> There were also calls for a change in the law, as the legislation at the time was an Act of the British Parliament of 1861—when Ireland was still part of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|United Kingdom]] —which declared that it was unlawful to "procure a miscarriage".<ref name=cbs/> On 16 November, the Irish [[Health Service Executive]] established an independent inquiry into the circumstances surrounding Halappanavar's death.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1116/breaking2.html|title=HSE still finalising details of Savita Halappanavar inquiry|work=The Irish Times| date=16 November 2012| accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref>
On Saturday 17 November, the [[Garda Síochána]] (Ireland's national police) estimated that between ten and twelve thousand protesters marched from [[Parnell Square]] to [[Merrion Square]] to demand a change in the law, whilst other rallies were also held across Ireland and in many other countries abroad.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1117/breaking4.html|title=Thousands attend Savita vigils around the country|work=The Irish Times|date=17 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref> On the same day, the Gardaí announced that they were assisting the coroner in the investigation into the death of Halappanavar.<ref name="it-gardai-assisting-coroner">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1117/breaking4.html|title=Gardaí assisting coroner in Savita Halappanavar case|date=17 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]}}</ref> Medical terminations had previously been performed at the University Hospital when complications arose in pregnancy, as it is permitted by Irish law to save the life of the woman. In an opinion piece in the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', Paul Bracchi speculated that an investigation would be carried out into why this did not occur in Halappanavar's case.
On Monday, 19 November, the Roman Catholic Bishops of Ireland met in response to Halappanavar's death and released a statement that the Catholic Church believes in the "equal and inalienable right to life of a mother and her unborn child" and that the Church has never taught that the life of an unborn child takes precedence over the mother.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/1119/x-case-legislation-abortion.html|title=Treatment that risks foetus can be 'ethically permissible' - Catholic bishops|work=RTÉ News | date=19 November 2012}}</ref>
Eilis O'Hanlon stated that in its initial coverage, ''The Irish Times'' had "opted to present what had happened as a simple morality tale" and that "the debate for the rest of the week was coloured entirely by The Irish Times's decision to reduce a complex personal tragedy, about which few facts were still known, to a rallying call."<ref name="metaanalysis">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/eilis-ohanlon-this-government-must-be-the-one-to-face-facts-3296910.html|title=Eilis O'Hanlon: This Government must be the one to face facts|last=Eilis O'Hanlon:|date=18 November 2012|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=21 November 2012}}</ref> An analysis in ''The Irish Times'' on 17 November stated: "There is much we do not know about the medical care Savita Halappanavar received" and "even before the full facts are established Ms Halappanavar’s tragedy has generated much national and international coverage" in both traditional and social media of which much has been "careful and sympathetic" but "much ... has been intemperate, intolerant and politicised."<ref name="change in debate">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2012/1117/1224326702600.html|title=Decisive change in the abortion debate|last=Noel Whelan|date=17 November 2012|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=21 November 2012}}</ref>
===Response from the medical community=== The staff of University Hospital, as well as members of Ireland's Health Services Executive (HSE) Regional Health Forum stated that there is no "Catholic ethos" that is impacting treatment provided.<ref name="humphreys">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/1116/1224326668071.html|title=Catholic ethos suggestion dismissed|last=Humphreys|first=Joe|date=16 November 2012|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=20 November 2012}}</ref>
Dr Sam Coulter-Smith, a consultant in [[obstetrics]] and [[gynaecology]] and a [[Trinity College Dublin|university master]] in the [[Rotunda Hospital]], one of the largest maternity hospitals in Ireland, said that it would be preferable to introduce legislation to bring in clarity, saying, "We really do need legislation in this area, otherwise we're going to be at risk of doctors working outside the law, and that's not appropriate."<ref name="We absolutely need legislation - Rotunda Master Dr Sam Coulter-Smith">{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/av/2012/1116/media-3436430.html|title=We absolutely need legislation - Rotunda Master Dr Sam Coulter-Smith|work=RTÉ|date=15 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121128092407/http://www.rte.ie/news/av/2012/1116/media-3436430.html|archivedate=28 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Rotunda head: No confusion">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/rotunda-head-no-confusion-574300.html|title= Rotunda head: No confusion|work=Irish Examiner|date=15 November 2012}}</ref> Dr Rhona Mahony, Master of the National Maternity Hospital, said: "It is very disappointing that, 20 years after the 'X-Case', we don't have legislation" and that women "need to know that they are going to get the appropriate health care that they need" while doctors "need to know that they are also protected in their ability to do their job."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/maternity-hospital-chief-women-and-doctors-need-protection-574284.html|title=Maternity hospital chief: Women and doctors need protection|date=15 November 2012|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=20 November 2012}}</ref> Peter Boylan, of the Irish Institute of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, said: "The current situation is like a [[sword of Damocles]] hanging over us. If we do something with a good intention, but it turns out to be illegal, the consequences are extremely serious for medical practitioners."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/23/world/europe/inquiry-sought-in-death-in-ireland-after-abortion-was-denied.html|title=Inquiry Sought in Death in Ireland After Abortion Was Denied|first=Douglas|last=Dalby|newspaper=The New York Times|date=22 November 2012}}</ref>
Microbiologist Dr. James Clair<ref name="Dr James Clair">{{cite web |url=http://www.muh.ie/index.php?option=com_qcontacts&view=contact&id=28%3Adr-james-clair&catid=47%3Aconsultant-directory&Itemid=84 |title=Dr James Clair |publisher=Mercy University Hospital, Cork, Ireland |accessdate=2012-11-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029075930/http://muh.ie/index.php?option=com_qcontacts&view=contact&id=28%3Adr-james-clair&catid=47%3Aconsultant-directory&Itemid=84 |archivedate=29 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> stated that the "main problem is being missed" in the case, suggesting that the real issue may be that the septicemia was caused by [[extended-spectrum beta-lactamase]] positive gram negative bacteria (ESBL), which "are now spreading rapidly within the Irish population" and are resistant to many known antibiotic treatments.<ref name="resistant">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/opinion/savitas-death-may-have-been-due-to-resistant-bacteria-strain-214431.html|title=Savita’s death may have been due to resistant bacteria strain|last=Dr J Clair|work=Irish Examiner|accessdate=21 November 2012}}</ref>
===Political response in 2012=== A week after the story broke, while the investigations were still ongoing, [[Taoiseach]] [[Enda Kenny]] stated: "I don't think we should say anything about this until we are in possession of all the facts."<ref name="itvnov17">{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/update/2012-11-14/enda-kenny-wants-all-the-facts-before-savita-action/|title=Enda Kenny wants 'all the facts' before Savita action -|date=17 November 2012|work=ITV News|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref>
Prior to publication of the reports, the Minister for Health, [[James Reilly (Irish politician)|James Reilly]], said that the public must not pre-judge the situation and further said that he was awaiting the results of the investigations, adding he had no evidence to suggest a so-called "Catholic ethos" at the University Hospital that prevented Halappanavar's life from being saved by a medical termination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/reilly-no-evidence-catholic-ethos-prevented-savitas-life-from-being-saved-574238.html |title=Reilly: No evidence Catholic ethos prevented Savita's life from being saved |publisher=Irish Examiner |date=14 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref> He has also stated that an inquiry into Halappanavar's death must stand up to international scrutiny.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/video-probe-must-stand-up-to-international-scrutiny-reilly-3294919.html|title=Video: Probe must stand up to international scrutiny - Reilly|work=Independent.ie|date=15 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012}}</ref>
[[Brian Walsh (Irish politician)|Brian Walsh]], a [[Fine Gael]] [[Teachta Dála|TD]] for [[Galway West (Dáil constituency)|Galway West]], said that Galway University Hospital had carried out terminations in recent years in accordance with the judgement by the Supreme Court in the X case and with the guidelines of the Irish Medical Council. He said that the University Hospital was not run or managed by any [Catholic] religious orders and did not have a so-called "Catholic ethos".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2012/1116/1224326668914.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130127061746/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/frontpage/2012/1116/1224326668914.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=27 January 2013 |title=Too soon to commit on abortion legislation, says Reilly |publisher=The Irish Times |date=16 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref>
[[Fianna Fáil]] leader [[Micheál Martin]] said that Halappanavar's death was tragic and harrowing. Martin said that Ireland had always aimed for a low death rate during pregnancy but that this was "cold comfort" to Halappanavar and her surviving family and relatives. He said that an independent inquiry was needed, with experts from outside the country to establish the full circumstances. He also responded on 17 November, saying that "legislating for the X case would not have stopped [the death of Savita Halappanavar]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.herald.ie/news/law-on-x-case-would-not-have-saved-savita-says-martin-3294869.html|title=Law on X Case would not have saved Savita, says Martin|work=Herald.ie|date=15 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012|last=Murphy|first=Cormac}}</ref> On 18 December 2012, after a panel of experts submitted its report to the Parliament recommending, "the government legislate the issue in order to clarify what the current laws actually do and do not permit", Ireland's then [[Minister for Health (Ireland)|Minister of Health]], [[James Reilly (Irish politician)|James Reilly]], stated "We will clarify in legislation and regulation what is available by way of treatment to a woman when a pregnancy gives rise to a threat to a woman’s life."<ref>{{cite news |title=Ireland’s Historic Abortion Shift and the Tragedy That Shadowed It|url=http://world.time.com/2012/12/19/irelands-historic-abortion-shift-and-the-tragedy-that-shadowed-it/ |date=19 December 2012 |publisher=TIME |accessdate=2012-12-20}}</ref>
===Response of pro-choice organisations in 2012=== [[Pro-choice]] campaigners highlighted at the time that the lack of legislation clarifying the limited circumstances in which abortion is legal in Ireland contributed to Halappanavar's death.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/termination-would-have-saved-savita-heartbroken-husband-3294638.html?start=3 |title='Termination would have saved Savita' - heartbroken husband |publisher=The Independent |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref> Several rallies and vigils were organised nationwide, calling for the Irish government to legislate in relation to abortion on the basis of the ''[[X Case|Attorney General v. X]]''. Campaigners argued that legislation remained outstanding at the time of Halappanavar's death despite the [[European Court of Human Rights]] having instructed the state to clarify its laws on abortion after finding in ''[[A, B and C v Ireland]]'' (2010) that the Republic of Ireland had violated the Convention by failing to provide an accessible and effective procedure by which a woman can have established whether she qualifies for a legal abortion under current Irish law.
Irish Choice Network allegedly emailed members, calling for an emergency meeting to discuss how to proceed with this "major news story".<ref>{{cite news|author=Reilly, Jerome |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/prochoice-activists-got-tipoff-on-tragic-death-3296844.html |title=Pro-choice activists got tip-off on tragic death |publisher=The Independent |date=18 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref>
In response to critics accusing pro-choice activists of exploiting Halappanavar's death, [[Kate Smurthwaite]] responded in a column in ''The Huffington Post'' titled "Yes, Savita Halappanavar's Death IS a Political Issue" in which she stated, "If I am ever a victim of an unjust legal discrepancy that infringes my human rights and leads to my untimely and unnecessary agonising death I want every man, woman and child on the streets immediately demanding that it never, ever be allowed to happen again."<ref name="huffpo">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/kate-smurthwaite/savita-halappanavar-abortion_b_2135674.html|title=Yes, Savita Halappanavar's Death IS a Political Issue|last=Kate Smurthwaite:|date=15 November 2012|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref>
===Response of pro-life organisations in 2012=== {{Abortion in the Catholic Church}} The Life Institute in Ireland has accused what it called "abortion campaigners" of exploiting Halappanavar's death to further the pro-choice agenda.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2012/1115/1224326607685.html|title=Lobby group accused of exploiting death|work=The Irish Times|date=15 November 2012|accessdate=17 November 2012|first=Ciara|last=Kenny}}</ref>
Michael Kelly of ''The Catholic World Report'' rejects claims that Ireland's abortion laws led to Halappanavar's death, writing that "medical experts and bioethicists have been quick to express their view that Ireland's ban on abortion had nothing to do with Mrs. Halappanavar’s death. They insist that guidelines from the Irish Medical Council are perfectly clear that pregnant women must be given all necessary medical treatment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicworldreport.com/Item/1751/after_tragedy_irish_abortion_laws_come_under_fire.aspx|title=After Tragedy, Irish Abortion Laws Come Under Fire|date=15 November 2012|work=The Catholic World Report|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> Father Shenan J. Boquet, president of [[Human Life International]], said that there was no evidence to indicate that "a Catholic ethos" prevented responsible treatment of the mother, and called news reports that that was the case "demonizing the church's position on abortion". He described the debate resulting from the event as "activism masquerading as compassion and moral outrage."<ref name="COL-2012-11-15">{{cite web|url=http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=48524|title=Human Life International Statement on the Death of Savita Halappanavar in Ireland|last=Boquet|first=Shenan J.|date=15 November 2012|work=Catholic Online|accessdate=16 November 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102192739/http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=48524|archivedate=2 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===International response=== There were protests outside the Irish embassies in [[London]],<ref name=bbc1/> [[Berlin]]<ref name="irishtimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1121/breaking13.html|title=Up to 70 people also protested outside the Irish embassy in Berlin tonight|date=21 November 2012|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="midigrrrl">{{cite news |url=http://www.youreonlymassive.com/berlin-vigil/|title=Vigil for Savita and Protest at Ireland’s Abortion ban, Irish Embassy, Berlin|date=21 November 2012|work=Midi Grrrl|accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> and [[Brussels]].<ref name="broadsheet.ie">{{cite news|url=http://www.broadsheet.ie/2012/11/22/last-night-in-brussels-2/|title=Last night in Brussels|date=22 November 2012|work=[[Broadsheet.ie]]|accessdate=12 February 2013}}</ref>
In [[India]], the then-[[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Indian Minister for External Affairs]], [[Salman Khurshid]], summoned the Indian ambassador to Ireland, Debashish Chakravarti, to India for deliberations over the issue.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/indian-woman-death-mea-summons-irish-ambassador-after-row-over-antiabortion-laws/305886-3.html|title=Savita death case: MEA summons Irish envoy after row over abortion, Updated|publisher=[[CNN-IBN]], IBN Live|work=IBN Live|date=16 November 2012}}</ref> Chakravarti later met [[Eamon Gilmore]], Ireland's [[Tánaiste]] (deputy prime minister) and [[Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade|foreign minister]], and promised to keep Halappanavar's husband up to date with the government's response.<ref name="toi">{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Salman-Khurshid-closely-following-developments-in-Savita-Halappanavar-death-case/articleshow/17270798.cms|title=Salman Khurshid closely following developments in Savita Halappanavar death case|date=18 November 2012|work=[[The Times of India]]|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref> [[Rajeev Chandrasekhar]], an independent member of the [[Rajya Sabha]] (the upper house of the [[Parliament of India]]) said, "The death of Savita Halappanavar should be pursued by family and Govt. of India as a case of human rights violation and murder. Instead of simply protesting, cases should be filed against the Govt. of Ireland and its leadership at the International Court of justice and United Nations Commission for Human Rights (UNHCR). This should move beyond protesting to where people are brought to account!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rajeev.in/News/human_rights_violation/Times_of_India.html |title=State take up her cause: CM Shettar Says Humanity Should Precede Legality |publisher=The Times of India |date=17 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-23}}</ref>
In an editorial on 17 November 2012, ''[[The Times of India]]'' said, "There appears to be a tendency to view this issue in terms of India versus Ireland or the Catholic faith against other religions. To fall prey to such tendencies would be a serious mistake and a great disservice to the memory of Savita. ... Adding a nationalist or communal tone to the debate detracts from the merit of argument rather than enhancing it."<ref name="toioped">{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-11-17/other-news/35171888_1_halappanavar-northern-ireland-savita-case|title=Savita's kin being consulted |date=17 November 2012|work=[[The Times of India]]|accessdate=19 November 2012}}</ref>
[[Amnesty International]] states that Halappanavar's death "illustrates [the] gap in Irish law" and asked the government of Ireland to change the law on abortion "in line with international human rights laws."<ref name="amnesty">{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/uk/Irish-govt-must-clarify-on-abortion-issue-Amnesty/articleshow/17253462.cms|title=Irish Government must clarify on abortion issue: Amnesty|newspaper=The Times of India|date=17 November 2012| accessdate=17 November 2012|last=Press Trust of India}}</ref> The executive director of Amnesty International in Ireland, [[Colm O'Gorman]], said that "successive Irish Governments have failed in their duty to provide necessary clarity on how this right is protected and vindicated, leaving women in Ireland in a very vulnerable position."<ref name=amnesty/>
==HSE inquiry 2012== On 19 November 2012, the HSE named Professor Sir [[Sabaratnam Arulkumaran]] to head a seven-member panel looking into the case. Arulkumaran is the head of obstetrics and gynaecology at [[St George's Hospital Medical School]] and is president-elect of the [[International Federation of Gynaecology and Obstetrics]]. The panel sought to uncover all the facts and "to identify any safety issues arising in this case".<ref name="ITnov19">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1119/breaking1.html|title=HSE unveils membership of Halappanavar inquiry team|date=19 November 2012|work=[[The Irish Times]]|pages=direct quote is from the video, at approx 1 min|accessdate=20 November 2012}}</ref>
On 20 November 2012, three members of the panel were asked to step down when Savita Halappanavar's husband, Praveen Halappanavar, indicated that he would not cooperate with the panel due to their connections as consultants to University Hospital. Arulkumaran has requested a meeting with Mr. Halappanavar.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2012/1121/breaking13.html|title=HSE announces Savita inquiry team replacements|date=21 November 2012|work=[[Irish Times]]|accessdate=22 November 2012}}</ref> On 21 November, the ''Irish Independent'' reported that Arulkumaran was being accused of being "pro-abortion" and promoting a "liberal" approach to abortion because of papers that he has published.<ref name="shambles">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/probe-into-savita-shambles-goes-from-bad-to-worse-3301343.html|title=Probe into Savita shambles goes from bad to worse|first1=Eilish |last1=O'Regan |first2=Greg |last2=Harkin|date=21 November 2012|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=21 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Arulkumaran report ===
The Arulkumaran report was published on 13 June 2013. It identified three "Key Causal Factors" for the death: inadequate assessment and monitoring; failure to offer all management options to a patient; and non adherence to clinical guidelines related to the prompt and effective management of sepsis. It made six recommendations for improvements in patient care in such situations. Most recommendations called for improvements in healthcare guideline, training and practices, and one recommendation called for legislative changes if necessary to allow for expediting delivery for clinical purposes. Additionally, it made three recommendations to address incidental factors.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|13–18}}
=== Key causal factors===
The report indicates the first key causal factor was inadequate assessment and monitoring. This would have allowed medical staff to recognise and respond to indicators that the infection was causing a deterioration in Savita's condition. Additionally, staff failed to devise a plan of care recognising that (1) the infection was the most likely cause of the patient's miscarriage, and, (2.) With increase in time following admission, and the rupture of the patient's membranes, the risk of infection and [[sepsis]] increases.
The panel identified the hospital's failure to offer all management options to a patient was a second key causal factor. The panel points out that the patient was "experiencing inevitable miscarriage of an early second trimester pregnancy where the risk to the mother increased with time from the time that membranes were ruptured."<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|13}}
The panel found that hospital staff failed to adhere to clinical guidelines which relate to severe sepsis and septic shock. These relate to timely and effective management of sepsis when it is diagnosed.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|13}}
In reviewing the care given to Halappanavar in light of clinical guidelines, the panel wrote: <blockquote>Rupture of membranes may be caused by infection and vomiting indicates that the patient was unwell increasing the possibility of infection becoming systemic to causing sepsis. At interview, clinicians indicated that their management decisions were guided by the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Green-top guidelines for the Management of Preterm Pre-labour Rupture of the Membranes (RCOG Green-top Guideline No.44 2006 amended 2010). The patient was commenced on erythromycin at 22.00hrs on the 22nd of October. Erythromycin is indicated for use prophylactically in preterm pre-labour rupture of the membranes in the absence of signs such as a faster pulse or lower blood pressure or raised temperature (Green-top Guidelines No 44 (2006 with amendment Oct 2010)). Erythromycin has also been shown to delay delivery which is beneficial in the management of preterm pre-labour rupture of the membranes but not in cases of inevitable miscarriage.However, in cases of preterm pre-labour rupture of the membranes where signs of sepsis occur, best practice guidelines promote that delivery is expedited.<p> The appropriate management of spontaneous rupture of the membranes in cases of inevitable miscarriage where infection is a possible underlying cause is somewhat different to the appropriate management of Preterm Pre-labour Rupture of the Membranes where the incidence of infection at presentation is lower and the survival of the fetus is more likely.<p>There are no accepted clear local, national or international guidelines on the management of inevitable early second trimester miscarriage (i.e. less than 24 weeks) including the management of miscarriage where there is prolonged rupture of the membranes. The reason for the absence of such guidelines may be that clinical practice in other jurisdictions would have led to an early termination of pregnancy in equivalent clinical circumstances. It is recommended that such guidelines be developed for such patients as a matter of urgency and they should be explicit in the guidance given as to when one should offer termination based on symptoms and signs of infection implying increasing health risk to the mother which may even threaten her life.<p>We recognise that such guidelines must be consistent with applicable law and that the guidance so urged may require legal change.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|58–59}}</blockquote>
===Recommendations of the Panel===
# Prompt introduction of a Maternity Early Warning Scoring Systems Chart for patients with pregnancy complications in gynaecology wards. This should be followed by a compliance audit. The chart should indicate a monitoring coupled with an escalating nursing, medical and multidisciplinary response.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|15}} # Introduction of mandatory induction and education on early recognition, monitoring and management of infection and sepsis. This includes severe sepsis and septic shock. # Development and implementation of national guidelines relating to infection and pregnancy, in addition to multidisciplinary educational programmes to improve care in such cases. In particular, there needs to be audited compliance with guidelines on management of infection, sepsis, and suspected sepsis in cases of inevitable miscarriage of an early second trimester pregnancy. This includes when there is a prolonged rupture of membranes, and increasing time from this point increases the risk to the mother. # Two sub-recommendations: ## Compliance with guidelines on the management of early second trimester inevitable miscarriage. This should recognise possible rapid patient deterioration, possibly within a few hours, from sepsis to severe sepsis to septic shock. It should also recognise the high mortality rate, of up to 60 percent, associated with this. These guidelines should include the same emphases as those for infection and pregnancy listed in recommendation 3.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|16}} The panel recommended such guidelines should include guidelines relating to expediting delivery for clinical reasons, including "medical and surgical termination" based on the expertise available and legal feasibility.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|17}} ## Clear statement of the legal context in which clinical professional judgement can be exercised in the best medical welfare interests of patients. The Oireachtas should consider the law including any necessary constitutional change and related administrative, legal and clinical guidelines in relation to the management of inevitable miscarriage in the early second trimester of a pregnancy. # The panel recommended improved communication practices between all relevant staff, and improvements in handover of acutely ill patients. Additionally, definitive tools for clearly communicating information relating to the deterioration of a woman's condition, consultation and/or handover to a higher level of care, according to ‘Improving patient handover – RCOG Good Practice No 12’ (Dec 2010).<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|17}} # Compliance of guidelines on the consultants' responsibilities, according to the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, "Responsibility of the consultant on call" (RCOG Good Practice No. 8 - March 2009). These indicate the need to involve senior medical staff due to difficulty coping with case load, or to consult on suspected serious cases. Midwives and nurses should be able to obtain help from senior nurse midwifery managers or the director of nursing on duty, and need to be able to contact the consultant if needed.<ref name=HSEreport/>{{rp|17}}
===Subsequent comments by Sabaratnam Arulkumaran=== In 2017, Arulkumaran commented that a significant contributing factor to her death was Ireland's restrictive abortion laws.<ref>{{cite news|title=Author of Savita Halappanavar report says 8th Amendment contributed to her death|url=https://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/author-of-savita-halappanavar-report-says-8th-amendment-contributed-to-her-death-810432.html|newspaper=BreakingNews.ie|date=24 April 2018}}</ref>
==HIQA report== The [[Health Information and Quality Authority]] (HIQA) published a report into the incident on 9 October 2013.<ref name=hiqa2103/> It found "following the rupture of her membranes, four-hourly observations including temperature, [[heart rate]], [[Breathing|respiration]] and [[blood pressure]] did not appear to have been carried out at the required intervals", noting "that though UHG [University Hospital Galway] had a guideline in place for the management of suspected [[sepsis]] and sepsis in obstetric care, the clinical governance arrangements were “not robust enough to ensure adherence to this guideline".<ref name=hiqa2103/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/savita-patient-report-1121411-Oct2013/|title=Damning Savita report details litany of hospital care failures|newspaper=TheJournal.ie|date=9 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/savita-halappanavar-missed-opportunities-timeline-1121510-Oct2013/|title=This shocking graph shows 13 "missed opportunities" in treatment of Savita|last=Daly|first=Susan|date=9 October 2013|work=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref>
==Aftermath== {{see also|Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013}} Partly in response to the protest movement after the death of Savita Halappanavar,<ref name="Savita Halappanavar effect">{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/world/1867644/report-savita-halappanavar-effect-irish-president-signs-first-abortion-bill-into-law|title=Savita Halappanavar effect|date=30 July 2013|work=[[DNA India]]|accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="The Hindu">{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/world/ireland-performs-first-legal-abortion-after-savita-case/article5052707.ece|title=Ireland performs first legal abortion|date=23 August 2013|work=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=30 July 2013|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> the Irish government introduced the ''[[Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013]]''. Having passed [[bicameralism|both Houses]] of the [[Oireachtas]] in July 2013, it was [[signed into law]] on 30 July by [[Michael D. Higgins]], the [[President of Ireland]].<ref name="ind29459937">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/president-higgins-signs-abortion-bill-into-law-29459937.html|title=President Higgins signs abortion bill into law|date=30 July 2013|work=[[Irish Independent]]|accessdate=30 July 2013}}</ref>
On 20 September 2013, Praveen Halappanavar's solicitor served legal proceedings against Galway University Hospital and separately against Doctor Katherine Astbury. The proceedings claim that Halappanavar's constitutional right to life had been breached and allege 30 issues of medical negligence.<ref name="Ind-Crawford">{{cite news|last=Crawford|first=Caroline|title=Savita's husband to sue her doctor for negligence|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/savitas-husband-to-sue-her-doctor-for-negligence-29596560.html|accessdate=26 September 2013|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=22 September 2013}}</ref><ref name="Times-Holland">{{cite news|last=Holland|first=Kitty|title=Halappanavar begins action against hospital, doctor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/ireland/irish-news/halappanavar-begins-action-against-hospital-doctor-1.1536230|accessdate=26 September 2013|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=21 September 2013}}</ref>
By May 2014, Praveen Halappanavar had emigrated to the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/tragic-savitas-husband-quits-ireland-for-the-us-30237521.html|title= Tragic Savita's husband quits Ireland for the US|date=2 May 2014|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]}}</ref> On 10 March 2016, Praveen Halappanavar settled the case with the HSE, after the HSE agreed to a confidential, six-figure cash settlement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/savita-halappanavar-husband-s-action-for-damages-settled-1.2567771|title=Savita Halappanavar : Husband’s action for damages settled|date=10 March 2016|first=Mary|last=Carolan|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/courts/savita-halappanavar-case-settled-for-six-figures-34534933.html|title= Savita Halappanavar case settled for six figures|first=Maeve|last=Sheehan|date=13 March 2016|accessdate=13 March 2016|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2016/0309/773765-savita-halappanavar/|title=Settlement reportedly made over Halappanavar case|date=9 March 2016|work=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref>
The issue of abortion law in Ireland continued to be an issue for political debate. In 2016-17 the Irish government convened a [[Citizens' Assembly (Ireland)|Citizens' Assembly]] to advise about the [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland|Eighth Amendment]].
On 20 May 2018, the parents of Halappanavar called for a Yes vote in Ireland's [[Thirty-sixth Amendment of the Constitution Bill 2018 (Ireland)|referendum on the repeal of the Eighth Amendment]] with her father saying, "I hope the people of Ireland will vote yes for abortion, for the ladies of Ireland and the people of Ireland. My daughter, she lost her life because of this abortion law, because of the diagnosis, and she could not have an abortion. She died."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/savita-s-father-calls-for-repeal-as-campaigns-target-undecided-1.3501906|title=Savita’s father calls for repeal as campaigns target undecided|last=Holland|first=Kitty|work=The Irish Times|date=20 May 2018|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref> On 25 of May 2018, the people of Ireland voted Yes to repeal the Eighth Amendment by a margin of 2 to 1.
On September 30, 2018, an open letter by [[Emma Watson]] to Halappanavar was published in ''Porter'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/women/emma-watson-savita-halappanavar-abortion-ireland-death-miscarriage-letter-porter-magazine-a8563131.html|title=EMMA WATSON PENS POWERFUL LETTER TO SAVITA HALAPPANAVAR, WHO DIED AFTER BEING DENIED AN ABORTION IN IRELAND|last=Barr|first=Sabrina|date=30 September 2018|access-date=1 October 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Sheila Hodgers]] * [[Eighth Amendment of the Constitution of Ireland]] * [[Abortion in the Republic of Ireland]] * [[Attorney General v. X]] * [[Protection of Life During Pregnancy Act 2013]] * [[PP v. HSE]]
==Sources== * {{cite web |url=http://hse.ie/eng/services/news/nimtreport50278.pdf |title=Investigation of Incident 50278 from time of patient’s self referral to hospital on the 21st of October 2012 to the patient’s death on the 28th of October, 2012 |last=Arulkumaran |first=Sabaratnam |author2=Cora McCaughan |author3=Cathriona Molloy |author4=Brian Marsh |author5=Geraldine Keohane |author6=James Walker |author7=Mary Horgan |date=13 June 2013 |publisher=Health Service Executive |format=PDF |accessdate=14 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818124037/http://www.hse.ie/eng/services/news/nimtreport50278.pdf |archivedate=18 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.hiqa.ie/system/files/Patient-Safety-Investigation-UHG.pdf |title=Investigation into the safety, quality and standards of services provided by the Health Service Executive to patients, including pregnant women, at risk of clinical deterioration, including those provided in University Hospital Galway, and as reflected in the care and treatment provided to Savita Halappanavar |publisher=Health Information and Quality Authority |format=PDF |date=7 October 2013 |accessdate=9 October 2013 }}
